insights.insight: Ad tech charges $5–$150 CPA to infer a purchase happened; this protocol settles at ~$0.10 per cryptographically verified receipt — a 50–200x cost delta that isn't a pricing advantage but a structural category difference.

With Chrome completing cookie deprecation and device fingerprinting increasingly blocked, no scaled cross-ecosystem signal exists that is both identity-free and purchase-verified — the protocol's DKIM-attested receipts fill exactly that gap.

Best Buy's entry as a top brand confirms the receipt layer captures physical retail alongside SaaS and digital spend, meaning a single consumer's laptop purchase and subscription renewal can appear in the same verified signal window — the cross-category targeting thesis is now evidenced, not theoretical.

Google, Apple, Stripe, and Microsoft each see a slice of commerce — intent, app purchases, payment amounts, or enterprise usage — but none see line-item purchase data across ecosystems without identity attachment; that combination does not exist elsewhere in the market.

Penetration across 15 active CBSAs shows a pulse pattern consistent with social graph propagation rather than paid acquisition, meaning the user base skews toward networked early adopters — a high-signal cohort for brands testing new commerce intelligence channels.

insights.topic: Closed-loop receipt apps as a false comparison
insights.insight: Fetch and Ibotta hold real purchase data but it is identity-attached, siloed, and not queryable by third-party brands; the structural difference here is verified purchase signals that are privacy-preserving and accessible across the ecosystem rather than locked inside a loyalty program.
